data: A Mirror ON Race in Medieval Europe

Decorations in a luxury copy of a Christian text show the different ways in which medieval people encountered and thought about race.

Le miroir de humaine saluation (The mirror of human salvation)
Flanders (present-day Belgium), ca. 1455 
Louis H. Silver Collection
Newberry VAULT Case MS 40

Medieval artists often represented Biblical figures as pale-skinned Europeans. In part, they did so because Christian thinkers taught that lighter colors like white symbolized goodness, purity, and holiness, while darker colors like black symbolized the opposite. Images like these contributed to the idea that those with white skin were superior to those without it.

Don Simone Camaldolese (active 1378-1405), illuminator
Camaldolese Gradual
Florence, Italy, between 1390 and 1395
Henry Probasco Collection
Newberry VAULT oversize Case MS 74, vol. 1

Medieval bookmakers knew the best materials for making luxury manuscripts like The Mirror of Salvation, came from locations outside Europe, like Syria (ink), Central and East Asia (pigments), and Africa (gold), largely through exchanges with Muslim traders. These precious books were physical reminders of how non-European, non-Christian cultures were present in medieval Europe, providing further opportunities for race making.


Abraham Cresques (d. 1387), cartographer
Portrait of Mansa Musa, ruler of Mali, holding a piece of gold
In Georges Grosjean (ed.), Mapamundi, The Catalan Atlas of the Year 1375 
Dietikon-Zurich, Switzerland: Urs Graf, 1978
Newberry Case oversize G1026 .M37 1978

Blackness was clearly present in medieval Christianity through figures like the Queen of Sheba, shown here offering jewels to King Solomon. Generations of Biblical scholars identified her as the bride proclaiming “I am Black but beautiful” in a passage from Song of Songs (verse 1:4 in medieval Bibles like this one).


Latin Bible
Spain, ca. 1300
